rename.from: Low resolution titlebar on Retina Macs on OSX 10.10
rename.to: Low resolution titlebar on Retina Macs on 10.10

body:
Since this is an app bundle, I know it's possible to fix this problem by adding:

``` XML
<key>NSHighResolutionCapable</key>
<true/>
```

To the app bundle's `Info.plist` file (located at `*.app/Contents/Info.plist` path).

In fact, I do not know of any other way except that. If you don't include that key, the app may or may not get treated as HiDPI-capable depending on some factors, which can result in low resolution window decorations, etc.

If someone knows an alternative reliable way to achieve this without needing to modify `Info.plist`, please share.

What @shurcooL said.

I will add a better plist template for the next release.

Thanks that worked! It's explained in the lower half of this page: https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/documentation/GraphicsAnimation/Conceptual/HighResolutionOSX/Explained/Explained.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40012302-CH4-SW10
Was this a change from 10.9 or has it always worked this way? I can't recall anyone mentioning this before 10.10 was released.

issue.title: Low DPI and wrong resolution in Mac OS X High Sierra.

repository.name: Bonzomatic
repository.description: Live shader coding tool and Shader Showdown workhorse

issue.body:
I cloned and compiled Bonzomatic on my Mac OS X 10.13.3 and I noticed two bug:
- GLFW seem to use the wrong DPI (the title bar is very blurry).
- The resolution is wrong. A small resolution will end up creating a much bigger window.

Here is a [screenshot](https://maeln.com/img/bonzo-bug-hidpi.png).
I selected a resolution of 1440x900 which is much smaller than my mac resolution (2 880x1 800, 220dpi) and the window is bigger than my screen.

It seem to be related with this [GLFW issue](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/issues/422).
I tried to manually add : 
```
<key>NSHighResolutionCapable</key>
<true/>
```

to the `Info.plist` of the App but the option "Open in low resolution" is still locked to true.

body:
If someone will end up here using search. This indeed fixes an issue but if does not for you, try to change application path. It appears that OSX caching plist partially. After I moved app to a /tmp (for testing) the option have applied.
Have fun.

FWIW: SDL can do this programmatically on MacOS, with the SDL_WINDOW_ALLOW_HIGHDPI flag. And it works, you get the window in hidpi mode or in normal mode depending on whether you set that flag or not, no matter if you don't even have a plist.
